verses.text: Whoever touches pitch will be stained by it; and anyone who associates with the arrogant will become like them.
verses.comment: The image of pitch (tar) is used to warn about the corrupting influence of bad company. This recalls Psalm 1:1, which blesses those who avoid the company of the wicked.

verses.text: Do not lift a burden beyond your strength, and do not associate with someone stronger or richer than yourself. How can a clay pot stand next to an iron pot? The clay pot will always be broken.
verses.comment: The proverb cautions about the dangers of unequal relationships, both for practical and moral reasons. See also Prov. 19:4 on the social risks of poverty.

verses.text: If the rich person wrongs the poor, the poor cry out; but if the poor wrong the rich, the rich have the power to bring them down.
verses.comment: Highlights the imbalanced justice between rich and poor. The spiritual interpretation points toward God's ultimate justice (see Prov. 22:7).

verses.text: If you are useful, the rich will make friends with you; but if you become poor, they will abandon you.
verses.comment: Reflects on human relationships determined by advantage, echoing Proverbs 19:7. This is a call to seek virtue rather than admiration from the world.

verses.text: If you own something, people will live with you; they will serve you for as long as you succeed.
verses.comment: The pursuit of material gain often leads to superficial friendships. True riches come from a life of virtue and grace.

verses.text: If you fall into hard times, they will hide from you. Verses like these uncover the fickleness of human affection.
verses.comment: This echoes the theme found in Proverbs about the instability of relationships based on wealth. A call for hope in lasting, spiritual friendships.

verses.text: Stay away from your enemies, and be careful with your friends.
verses.comment: Cautious wisdom is advised even among friends. Christ calls us to love our enemies, but also to be wise as serpents (Matthew 10:16).

verses.text: A friend will sometimes turn into an enemy, and reveal your quarrels to shame you.
verses.comment: Even Jesus was betrayed by a close friend (Ps. 41:9; John 13:18), showing this is not a uniquely human problem.

verses.text: Let no one put you to shame by speaking against you, and when you meet with someone wealthy, remain silent.
verses.comment: Humility before the powerful is wisdom. Such humility prepares the heart for grace (Luke 18:14).

verses.text: Do not exalt yourself, lest you be cast down, nor draw near only to be rejected.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches a similar principle in Luke 14:8-11. True honor is received, not seized.

verses.text: Do not stand far off, lest you be forgotten.
verses.comment: Balance between humility and presence is advised here—neither pride nor neglect, but a healthy sense of self rooted in God’s call.

verses.text: Do not think yourself equal to a superior, nor trust in excessive words. Many have been deceived by their own pride.
verses.comment: Pride leads to a fall (Prov. 16:18). Spiritual wisdom lies in humility.

verses.text: If a powerful person invites you, be reserved, for someone greater than you may be invited; then you will be humbled.
verses.comment: Again, this reflects Jesus’ teaching on choosing the lowest place (see Luke 14:10).

verses.text: Do not offend, so you are not pushed away; and do not stand far away, lest you be forgotten.
verses.comment: This verse echoes the earlier theme: finding the golden mean between presumption and timidity.

verses.text: Do not force your way into conversation, and do not crowd others with your talk.
verses.comment: A gentle tongue and discerning silence mark true wisdom (see also James 1:19).

verses.text: Do not be greedy for food at someone else's table, or take advantage of their generosity.
verses.comment: The warnings about covetousness point to the virtue of temperance (self-restraint). In Christian tradition, such balance is a fruit of the Spirit (Gal. 5:22-23).

verses.text: A wise and disciplined man will be careful in all things, but the foolish and brash will offend with their boldness.
verses.comment: Wisdom is always paired with prudence, a quality highly valued in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: If a rich person calls you, he may use you; he will smile at you and test you with his words.
verses.comment: Such warnings uncover the deceptive nature of flattery. Throughout Scripture, true worth comes in God’s sight—not from the rich or influential.

verses.text: Again and again, he will lavish you with food and drink, until he has exhausted you two or three times, and finally he will mock you.
verses.comment: This demonstrates the fleeting nature of worldly approval. Earthly honors are temporary; spiritual rewards are eternal (cf. Matt. 6:19-20).

verses.text: If you do not do as he says, he will abandon you, and the only thing you will hear from him is contempt.
verses.comment: Worldly relationships often come with conditions. Christ calls us to unconditional love and faithfulness.

verses.text: Guard yourself against being deceived, and pay attention, lest you suffer disgrace.
verses.comment: This is a call to vigilance and discernment—qualities encouraged throughout wisdom literature and vital in the Christian life (1 Pet. 5:8).

verses.text: When you hear these things, awake from sleep, and in all your life, love the Lord and call upon Him for help.
verses.comment: A keynote of the spiritual life: vigilance and prayer (cf. Luke 21:36). In Christ, such devotion is fulfilled perfectly.

verses.text: A poor man is honored for his wisdom, but a rich man is honored for his wealth.
verses.comment: Worldly values elevate achievements, not virtue. This anticipates the teaching of Jesus about the first being last and the last first (Matt. 19:30).

verses.text: If someone is great in poverty, how much more when he has wealth? But if someone is worthless in poverty, how much more disgraceful will he be in wealth?
verses.comment: Here is a subtle encouragement toward spiritual riches, seen as the foundation of any lasting honor, with a hint at the biblical tradition of 'poverty of spirit' (Matt. 5:3).

verses.text: A poor person may be admired for wisdom and despised for riches.
verses.comment: Earthly measures are fickle. The true treasure is found in wisdom, viewed as a gift received through faith and practice in the mystery of Christ.

verses.text: When a rich man speaks, everyone keeps silent, and his word is praised to the clouds; but when a poor man speaks, people say, 'Who is this?' And if he stumbles, they push him down even further.
verses.comment: A meditation on the injustice and partiality of men. The wisdom literature points beyond earthly life to a final judgment, where all will be seen in the light of God’s justice and mercy.
